Five St. Louis Park High School seniors have recently been recognized by the National Merit Scholarship Program as National Merit Semifinalists. The five seniors are Thorwald Anderson, Daniel Goldenberg, Gabriel Kaplan, Dahlia Krebs, and Joshua Krueger. They are among 288 students from Minnesota and approximately 16,000 students from across the country to be named semifinalists this year.

National Merit Semifinalists are selected based on scores from the PSAT (Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test) and are now eligible to compete for scholarships worth more than $30 million that will be awarded in the spring of 2021. Semifinalists score in the top 1% of the approximately 1.5 million students who took the PSAT as juniors.

Semifinalists will be notified in February if they have advanced to Finalist standing. Then, beginning in March and continuing to mid-June, around 7,600 students will be notified that they have been selected to receive a National Merit Scholarship award.

St. Louis Park High School senior Aaron Ellingson has been named an All-American Athlete by the National High School Strength Coaches Association (NHSSCA). Ellingson is one of 27 male athletes across the country to receive the award this year, and the first ever from St. Louis Park High School.

The award is given to high school athletes who demonstrate achievement on and off the field in regards to strength and conditioning, athletic performance, academics, and leadership.

“Participating in athletics at St. Louis Park High School has been a positive experience for me because of the people I have met and the life-long lessons I have learned throughout the years,” Ellingson said. “From the coaches to the players, everyone is very nice and many of them will become life-long friends for me. Being at a high school that encourages athletes to play multiple sports is something that I appreciate and is definitely not the case in many high schools around the Twin Cities.”

Learn more about Aaron and his athletic and academic accomplishments by visiting www.slpschools.org.

Congratulations to St. Louis Park High School junior Thor Anderson, who recently learned that he earned the highest possible ACT composite score of 36.

Typically, less than one half of 1% of students who take the ACT earn a perfect score. Of the 1.8 million U.S. high school students who took the ACT in 2019, only 4,878 earned a perfect score. The ACT is a college-readiness exam that measures skills in English, Math, Reading, and Science.

“I was really happy to find out about my score,” Anderson said. “I had spent some time preparing, and had taken the test previously, so I knew what to expect, but I still did much better than I expected.”

Anderson is a co-leader of the High School’s environmental club Roots and Shoots, participates in Quiz Bowl, is a member of the German Club, and plays percussion in pit for the school’s musicals.

Learn more about Thor by visiting the District website at www.slpschools.org.

Kids Place Childcare to reopen for the summer

The Governor’s most recent Executive Order 20-57 for the summer school period informs that school districts may provide childcare to all children but must continue to prioritize onsite care for eligible children of critical workers.

Under this order, Kids Place Childcare is able reopen to families for the summer period, June 15 – August 21, 2020. The program will be required to follow social distancing and hygiene guidelines laid out by the Minnesota Department of Education and the Minnesota Department of Health. These guidelines will require more programming space and staffing thereby potentially limiting the number of children we can serve.

If you are interested in enrolling your child, please register by May 22 by going online to https://slpcommunityed.com/child-care/. We will notify you as soon as possible if we can approve your contract as space allows. Kids Place says THANK YOU for your patience as they work through the details of these unprecedented times.

Congratulations to St. Louis Park High School junior Leo Dworsky, who has been named one of five 2020 Minnesota Varsity Showcase Artists by Classical Minnesota Public Radio (MPR).

This is the tenth year that Classical MPR has hosted the Minnesota Varsity competition, which is open to vocal and instrumental student artists ages 14 through 18 across the state. Entries that advance past the first round of judging are invited to MPR studios to create a professional recording. A panel of judges from the local music community then picks four showcase artists, while a fifth artist is chosen by MPR listeners through an audience vote. This year’s audience favorite was Dworsky, who submitted a vocal piece titled “Ich liebe dich” by Ludwig van Beethoven.

Visit https://bit.ly/SLPleo to listen to Dworsky's submission. Visit www.slpschools.org for a full story about Dworsky.

🏆 The St. Louis Park Human Rights Commission presented the 2019 Human Rights Award to Kristen Pehl, Meghan Malone, Vanessa Buth and Rachel Lebow at the Feb. 3 city council meeting. The Human Rights Award recognizes individuals, groups, organizations or businesses that have made an outstanding contribution toward increasing understanding and cooperation between people of different backgrounds in St. Louis Park.

HOPE Speaks is a free six-week class designed to address issues of race and racism among families with children in grades 3 – 5. The class examined participants feelings and attitudes about race, their blind spots, white privilege and white fragility, and how to start having the difficult and necessary conversations about challenging assumptions and combating racism.

"I’m excited about what this space will offer for not only our students and staff, but the community at large,” Middle School Library Media Specialist Greg Holmbeck said.

Kids Voting USA is a nonpartisan, grassroots-driven voter education program committed to creating lifelong voting habits in children, increasing family communication about citizenship, and encouraging greater adult voter turnout.

Results will be posted on the District website later this evening.

This year, Echo is the only student newspaper from the state of Minnesota that has been named a finalist. The Pacemaker is the highest award the NSPA gives out. Winners of the Pacemaker Award will be announced at the National High School Journalism Convention in Washington D.C., on Nov. 21-24.

Visit www.slpschools.org to read the entire story and list of individual and staff accolades.

The racial equity instructional coaches are supervised by Principal on Special Assignment Freida Bailey.
